arguments.name: Dark Mode Feature Implementation
arguments.description: Project to track all tasks related to implementing dark mode support across our application.

arguments.name: Implement Dark Mode Feature
arguments.problem_statement: Users have requested a dark mode option to reduce eye strain in low-light environments and improve battery life on OLED displays. Currently, the application only supports light mode, which can be uncomfortable to use at night or in dimly lit settings.
arguments.success_criteria:
- Users can toggle between light and dark modes from settings
- All UI components render correctly in both modes with appropriate contrast ratios (WCAG AA minimum)
- Dark mode applies consistently across all screens and views
- System theme detection automatically switches to dark mode on supported platforms when system setting is dark
- Performance impact of theme switching is negligible (< 50ms transition time)
arguments.description: Implement a comprehensive dark mode feature that allows users to switch between light and dark themes. The implementation should follow accessibility guidelines, maintain consistency across all UI components, and provide a smooth user experience with minimal performance overhead.

results.task_name: Break down a feature into tasks

arguments.name: Implement User Notifications for Workunit Updates
arguments.problem_statement: Currently, users are not notified when workunits they are involved in (e.g., assigned to, mentioned in, or following) undergo significant changes such as status updates, priority changes, due date modifications, or new tasks being added. This lack of visibility leads to delays, missed deadlines, and reduced collaboration efficiency.
arguments.success_criteria: Users receive timely, relevant notifications via email and/or in-app alerts when: (1) a workunit they are assigned to has its status changed; (2) a task is created or updated within a workunit they follow; (3) they are mentioned in a comment or description; (4) due dates are approaching or missed. Notifications must be configurable per user, support batched/digest options, and maintain an audit log of sent notifications.
arguments.description: This feature requires building a notification infrastructure that monitors workunit and task changes, determines relevance based on user roles/permissions/following status, formats messages, and delivers them via preferred channels (email, in-app). Key components include: event listeners for workunit/task updates, notification preference management, templating system, delivery mechanisms (async workers), and analytics/logging.

arguments.name: Notifications Infrastructure
arguments.description: Project to track development of the user notification system for workunit updates.

arguments.title: Define notification event schema and core data model for audit log
arguments.description: Design the structure of notification events (e.g., workunit_status_changed, task_assigned, mention_received), including fields like actor_id, target_user_ids, event_type, payload, timestamp, and delivery status. Define database schema for storing these events and their audit history.

arguments.title: Quarterly Audit Review: Authentication Workunits
arguments.content: During the quarterly audit, this workunit was reviewed. Its current status is confirmed as 'active'. No changes to scope or priorities were identified during this review.

arguments.title: Architectural Decision: Use WebSockets for Real-time Notifications
arguments.content:
We have decided to use WebSockets instead of polling for our real-time notification feature. This decision was made after considering the following tradeoffs:

WebSockets advantages:
- Lower latency: Messages are delivered instantly rather than waiting for polling intervals
- Reduced server load: No need for frequent HTTP requests from all clients
- Better user experience: Truly real-time updates without delays
- More efficient bandwidth usage for frequent updates

WebSockets considerations:
- Increased server complexity: Need to manage persistent connections
- Scaling challenges: Requires connection management infrastructure (e.g., Redis pub/sub, WebSocket clusters)
- Firewall/proxy compatibility: Some corporate networks may block WebSocket connections
- Resource usage: Persistent connections consume server resources even when idle

Polling alternatives considered but rejected:
- Simple implementation but creates unnecessary network traffic
- Higher latency depending on polling frequency
- More resource-intensive at scale due to frequent HTTP requests
- Less responsive user experience

Implementation approach will include fallback mechanisms for environments where WebSockets are blocked and proper connection pooling to handle scaling requirements.
